text: investigation as follows:

text: â€œFamily assessmentâ€ means the collection of information necessary to
label: BODY

text: determine:
label: BODY

text: a. The immediate safety needs of the child;
label: BODY

text: b. The protective and rehabilitative services needs of the child and family
label: BODY

text: that will deter abuse or neglect;
label: BODY

text: c. Risk of future harm to the child; and
label: BODY

text: d. Alternative plans for the childâ€™s safety if protective and rehabilitative
label: BODY

text: services are indicated and the family is unable or unwilling to participate in
label: BODY

text: services. These arrangements may be made in consultation with the
label: BODY

text: caretaker(s) of the child.

text: "Investigation" means the collection of information to determine:
label: BODY

text: during the investigation.

text: Authorities
label: BODY

text: The Code of Virginia grants CPS workers the authority to conduct family assessments
label: BODY

text: and investigations in response to a valid report of suspected child abuse or neglect.
label: BODY

text: Generally, the power to enforce the worker's authority lies with the courts.  For example,
label: BODY

text: if an individual refuses to allow the worker to conduct the family assessment or refuses
label: BODY

text: to talk to the worker, the worker may file a petition requesting that the court require the
label: BODY

text: individual to cooperate.   An individual's refusal to cooperate does not relieve the local
label: BODY

text: department of the responsibility to complete the family assessment or investigation
label: BODY

text: because it has been initiated due to a valid report of abuse or neglect.  These au-
label: BODY

text: thorities are applicable only during the conduct of the family assessment or investigation
label: BODY

text: Authority to Interview the Child
label: BODY

text: 22VAC40-705-60(1). [When responding to valid complaints or reports
label: BODY

text: local departments have the following authority] To talk to any child
label: BODY

text: suspected of being abused and/or neglected, or child's siblings,
label: BODY

text: without the consent of and outside the presence of the parent or
label: BODY

text: other caretaker, as set forth by Â§ 63.2-1518 of the Code of Virginia.
label: BODY

text: If the CPS worker talks to the child without the parentâ€™s or guardianâ€™s prior knowledge,
label: BODY

text: the CPS worker must notify the parent or guardian concerning the interview as soon as
label: BODY

text: possible.
label: BODY

text: Parent or Guardian Refuses to Allow Child to be Interviewed
label: BODY

text: The worker may consult with local county/city attorney to determine
label: BODY

text: whether to petition the court to request access to the child if denied
label: BODY

text: access.
label: BODY

text: CPS Worker May Exclude School Personnel From Interview
label: BODY

text: If the CPS worker interviews the child at school, the worker may exclude
label: BODY

text: school personnel from the interview in order to protect the family's right to
label: BODY

text: privacy.

text: 3.4.1 Exigent Circumstances Exist
label: HH3

label: BODY

text: exist for emergency removal of a child from the custody of his parent or
label: BODY

text: guardian.

label: BODY

text: action. The following circumstances must exist to remove a child without

label: BODY

text: The circumstances of the child are such that
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: An initial safety assessment is conducted at the beginning of a family assessment or

text: investigation.  The purpose of the initial safety assessment and safety plan is to:
label: BODY

text: â€¢ Assess whether any children are currently in immediate danger of serious

label: BODY

text: Safety Assessments differ from Risk Assessments in that the purpose is to assess a
label: BODY

text: Immediate Child Safety and Family Needs
label: BODY

text: Safety must be determined for each child and the safety conclusion based on the least
label: BODY

text: safe child if there is more than one child in the family.  To ensure that the safety of the
label: BODY

text: child is appropriately assessed in each family assessment and investigation, the local
label: BODY

text: department must complete an initial safety assessment at the first meaningful contact
label: BODY

text: with the family and document the results in the automated data system.
label: BODY

text: The safety assessment provides structured questions concerning the danger of
label: BODY

text: immediate harm or maltreatment to a child.  This information guides the decision about
label: BODY

text: whether the child may remain in the home with no intervention, may remain in the home
label: BODY

text: with safety interventions in place, or must be removed from the home.  This is an
label: BODY

text: appropriate time for the local department to consider convening a family partnership
label: BODY

text: meeting if necessary to address ongoing safety planning.
label: BODY

text: There is a Safety Assessment Checklist in the Appendix that can be used to evaluate
label: BODY

text: safety factors as well as protective factors that are to be considered along with the
label: BODY

text: elements that underlie child safety, including THREAT, HARM, SEVERITY,
label: BODY

text: VULNERABILITY, AND IMMINENCE.  These elements provide a context for the safety
label: BODY

text: factors.
label: BODY

text: For example, a 3 year old child may be more vulnerable and more threatened with
label: BODY

text: severe harm by an out of control parent than a 13 year old, but even the 3 year old may
label: BODY

text: be deemed safe if the parent has just been taken away by the police and a responsible
label: BODY

text: adult is available â€“ so there is no severe nor imminent threat of harm to the vulnerable
label: BODY

text: child.

text: 1.1   Assess Immediate Danger to the Child
label: H2

text: The initial safety assessment focuses on the child and the childâ€™s immediate
label: BODY

text: needs.  Factors to consider when assessing the immediate situation of the child
label: BODY

text: include:
label: BODY

text: Whether the child has sustained a mental or physical injury
label: BODY

text: warranting immediate attention or care;
label: BODY

text: b.       Whether an emergency or crisis situation exists meriting
label: BODY

text: immediate action to protect the child;
label: BODY

text: Whether the child is at risk of serious abuse or neglect
label: BODY

text: in the near future.
label: BODY

text: Assess Immediate Needs of the Family
label: BODY

text: After assessing the immediate safety needs of the child, the worker must
label: BODY

text: evaluate the immediate needs of the family.  Factors to consider include:
label: BODY

text: If the child has been injured or harmed, whether the family
label: BODY

text: has the capabilities or capacity to protect the child from
label: BODY

text: further harm;
label: BODY

text: Whether an emergency or crisis situation exists and the
label: BODY

text: familyâ€™s ability to cope;
label: BODY

text: Whether any other family members are at risk of harm or
label: BODY

text: danger;
label: BODY

text: d.       What are the familyâ€™s capabilities to ensure the safety of the
label: BODY

text: child or children in the near future.
label: BODY

text: Make Safety Decision
label: BODY

text: After safety and protective factors have been assessed, the CPS worker must
label: BODY

text: make a decision about the safety of the child(ren) in the home.  The safety
label: BODY

text: decision should be made on the basis of the needs of the least safe child in the
label: BODY

text: home, if there is more than one child.  One of the following safety decisions must
label: BODY

text: be determined and documented in the automated data system and shared with
label: BODY

text: the family.
label: BODY

text: A. SAFE: There are no children likely to be in immediate danger of moderate to
label: BODY

text: serious harm at this time.  No safety plan is required.
label: BODY

text: B. CONDITIONALLY SAFE: Safety interventions are in place and have resolved
label: BODY

text: the unsafe situation for the present time.  A safety plan is required to document
label: BODY

text: the interventions.
label: BODY

text: C. UNSAFE:  Without controlling intervention(s) a child is in immediate danger of
label: BODY

text: serious harm.  A court order or safety plan is required to document intervention.
label: BODY

text: Safety Decision and Family Partnership Meeting
label: BODY

text: The local department should schedule a family partnership meeting when
label: BODY

text: the worker assesses the childâ€™s safety to be in jeopardy or at risk of
label: BODY

text: removal or out of home placement. However, safety concerns are
label: BODY

text: paramount and necessary action to address safety issues shall not be
label: BODY

text: delayed. The family partnership meeting should be scheduled within 24
label: BODY

text: hours after safety issues have been identified and the agency is
label: BODY

text: considering removal, and occur before the 5 day court hearing in cases
label: BODY

text: after the emergency removal. Emergency removal prompts the need to

text: Develop Safety Plan
label: BODY

text: When the child is determined to be Conditionally Safe or Unsafe, the CPS worker must
label: BODY

text: determine what services or actions need to occur by developing a safety plan.  The
label: BODY

text: Virginia Administrative Code 22VAC40-705-10 defines safety plan:
label: BODY

text: "Safety plan" means an immediate course of action designed to
label: BODY

text: protect a child from abuse or neglect.
label: BODY

text: A safety plan must be made to ensure the immediate protection of the child.  When
label: BODY

text: possible, the worker needs to develop the safety plan with the cooperation of the child's
label: BODY

text: parent(s) or guardian(s).  The CPS worker must determine what actions are necessary
label: BODY

text: to assure the child's immediate safety.  If the actions needed to assure the safety of the
label: BODY

text: child cannot be put in place, alternative steps must be taken that can include court
label: BODY

text: intervention.  The safety plan and the CPS workerâ€™s efforts to develop the safety plan
label: BODY

text: with the family must be documented in the record.  A copy of the safety plan shall be left
label: BODY

text: with the caretaker of the child and/or the alleged abuser.  A Safety Plan format is
label: BODY

text: located in the Appendix.
label: BODY

text: Whenever possible the caretaker(s) should sign the safety plan along with the worker,
label: BODY

text: Reassessing Safety
label: BODY

text: Safety assessment is both a process and a document. The process of assessing child
label: BODY

text: safety is ongoing throughout the life of the CPS referral and ongoing case as
label: BODY

text: information is gathered with each contact.  While the initial safety decision and safety
label: BODY

text: plan are documented in the automated data system, any subsequent changes in safety
label: BODY

text: assessed in referrals or ongoing cases in the following circumstances should be
label: BODY

text: documented in the automated data system as well:
label: BODY

text: A change in family circumstances such that one or more safety factors
label: BODY

text: previously present are no longer present;
label: BODY

text: A change in information known about the family in that one or more safety
label: BODY

text: factors not present before are present now; or
label: BODY

text: A change in ability of safety interventions to mitigate safety factors and
label: BODY

text: require changes to the safety plan.
label: BODY

text: When safety is reassessed, the safety plan should be reviewed and revised
label: BODY

text: accordingly.  A family partnership meeting may be considered if safety concerns
label: BODY

text: escalate.
label: BODY

text: Conduct Family Assessment
label: BODY

text: 22VAC40-705-70(B). When completing a family assessment, the
label: BODY

text: local department shall gather all relevant information in collaboration
label: BODY

text: with the family, to the degree possible, in order to determine the
label: BODY

text: child and family services needs related to current safety or future
label: BODY

text: risk of harm to the child.
label: BODY

text: The family assessment is a process of gathering and evaluating information and
label: BODY

text: formulating conclusions regarding family functioning specific to child
label: BODY

text: abuse/neglect, the presenting complaint allegations, and family needs related to
label: BODY

text: child safety and risk of future abuse or neglect.
label: BODY

text: The family assessment is a child centered, family focused, participatory process that is
label: BODY

text: done with the family. The family assessment builds on family strengths.  It identifies
label: BODY

text: parental capacities and resources within the family and the community.  The process is
label: BODY

text: designed to incorporate parent/caretaker perceptions of child safety, address the
label: BODY

text: presenting complaint, and determine service needs related to potential maltreatment of
label: BODY

text: the child.  The family assessment can and should include the active involvement of all
label: BODY

text: members of the family and significant others in the extended family or community, as
label: BODY

text: appropriate.

label: H2

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 3. The child protective services worker shall observe the family
label: H2

text: environment, contact pertinent collaterals, and review pertinent records in
label: BODY

text: consultation with the family.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: family assessment or investigation may be made with the family members together.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: automated data system.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Face-to-Face Interview with the Alleged Victim Child
label: BODY

text: The CPS worker must conduct a face-to-face interview with the alleged
label: BODY

text: victim child and should conduct this face-to-face contact within the
label: BODY

text: response priority level assigned.  During the interview, the CPS worker
label: BODY

text: should inform the child what will occur during the assessment process.
label: BODY

text: The CPS worker should observe the child and document the child's
label: BODY

text: recollection and perception of the allegations.  The CPS worker should
label: BODY

text: note the child's emotional and physical condition (including any injury).
label: BODY

text: The CPS worker should learn about the child's needs and capabilities for
label: BODY

text: the purposes of risk assessment and service planning.  The CPS worker
label: BODY

text: must document all interviews and attempted interviews in the automated
label: BODY

text: data system.

label: BODY

text: the caretaker is prevented or severely limited in performing child caring tasks.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: impairs the caretakerâ€™s ability to provide for the childâ€™s basic needs to the extent
label: BODY

text: that the childâ€™s safety or health is jeopardized.  Incapacitation may occur as a
label: BODY

text: result of the caretakerâ€™s use of controlled substances to the extent that the
label: BODY

text: 11.6 Factors to Determine if Medical Neglect Has Occurred
label: HH3

text: It is the parentâ€™s responsibility to determine and obtain appropriate medical,
label: BODY

text: mental and dental care for a child.  What constitutes adequate medical treatment
label: BODY

text: for a child cannot be determined in a vacuum, but rather, each case must be
label: BODY

text: decided on its own particular facts.

label: BODY

text: treatment and whether the child was harmed or placed at risk of harm as a result
label: BODY

text: of the failure.  Cultural and religious child-rearing practices and beliefs that differ
label: BODY

text: from general community standards should not be considered a basis for medical
label: BODY

text: neglect, unless the practices present a specific danger to the physical or
label: BODY

text: emotional safety of the child.

label: BODY

label: HH3

label: BODY

text: 11.12 Founded Disposition & Identity of Abuser is Unknown
label: HH3

text: 9  In Robinson v. Commonwealth, 231 Va. 142, 341 S.E.2d 159 (1986), the Virginia Supreme Court stated, "[I]n a
label: BODY

text: long line of cases, spanning almost thirty years, we have made clear that polygraph examinations are so thoroughly
label: BODY

text: unreliable as to be of no proper evidentiary use whether they favor the accused, implicate the accused, or are agreed
label: BODY

text: upon to by both parties."  Virginia courts have not specifically addressed the use of polygraphs in administrative
label: BODY

text: hearings.  However, in light of the courts' strong opposition to using results of polygraph testing in evidence, we see
label: BODY

text: no principled distinction between the use of a polygraph in court and use in an administrative hearing.  In Dept. of
label: BODY

text: Public Safety v. Scruggs, 79 Md. App. 312, 556 A.2d 736 (1989), the court acknowledged that administrative
label: BODY

text: agencies are not bound by the strict rules of evidence, but stated that such evidence must be competent.  The court
label: BODY

text: found polygraph evidence so unreliable as to deem it "incompetent" evidence.  The Supreme Court relied on
label: BODY

text: Robinson in 2004 in Elliott v. Commonwealth, 267 Va. 396, 593 S.E.2d 270 (2004).

text: 13.2   Determine the Risk Level for Founded Investigation
label: H2

text: The risk assessment must be categorized into one of the following three levels
label: BODY

text: and documented in the automated data system:
label: BODY

text: High Risk

label: BODY

text: the child is in jeopardy of abuse or neglect, and that intervention is
label: BODY

text: necessary in order to protect the child or other children.
label: BODY

text: Moderate Risk
label: BODY

text: The worker's assessment of risk related factors indicates that the child or
label: BODY

text: other children are in possible jeopardy, but that a positive change in the
label: BODY

text: situation is likely to occur with minimal intervention.
label: BODY

text: Low Risk

text: The worker's assessment of risk related factors indicates that the situation
label: BODY

text: can and will be changed, that no additional intervention is necessary, and
label: BODY

text: that the child or other children are at no reasonably assessable risk of
label: BODY

text: abuse or neglect.
